bestBHT.bht: The lady mentioned here may in fact refer to a Church, as proposed by the first-tier source. The elect sister could be the children of a deceased relative of this lady, who lived in Ephesus and were known as members of John's church there. This underscores the importance of early conversion in children and its positive impact on the world. We are encouraged to have open minds, love the truth, treat others with kindness, and be hospitable and charitable to all, irrespective of their background or beliefs.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: confesses that the non-mention of the “lady" herself here
seems rather to favor the hypothesis that a Church
Albert Barnes: What is more lovely to the view than such a household? What is better fitted to make an impression on the world favorable to religion?

No greater blessing can descend on a family than the early conversion of children; and, just as angels rejoice over one sinner that is converted, we should rejoice when the children of our friends are brought to a knowledge of the truth, and devote themselves to God in early life.

We are to have minds open to conviction. We are to love the truth, and always be ready to follow it. We are not to be prejudiced against anything. We are to treat all people with kindness; to be true, and just, and faithful in our contact with everyone; to be hospitable, and always ready to do good to any who are needy, whatever their name, color, rank, or opinions.
Archibald T. Robertson: Of thine elect sister (της αδελφης σου της εκλεκτης).
Apparently children of a deceased sister of the lady of verse 2 John 1:1.
Who lived in Ephesus and whom John knew as members of his church there.
John Gill: Not the members of a sister church, as some think; but the children of one who was the sister of this lady, according to the flesh.
she was either a very famous and excellent person, or rather one chosen of God likewise unto eternal life and salvation.
very likely those sister's children lived at Ephesus, where John resided.
John Wesley: The children of thy elect or Christian sister - Absent, if not dead, when the apostle wrote this.

bhtAttempts.bht: It is suggested by the commentary that the lady mentioned in the verse may refer to a Church rather than an individual. The elect sister mentioned may be the children of a deceased sister of the lady, who lived in Ephesus and were known as members of John's church there. This passage reminds us of the importance of the early conversion of children and the positive influence it can have on the world. We are encouraged to have open minds, love the truth, treat others with kindness, and be hospitable and charitable to all, regardless of their background or beliefs.
